qas.question: The word Slav could be derived from what Middle English word?
The origin of what Byzantine term is disputed?
The Byzantine Greek σκλάβος sklábos "slave," which was in turn apparently derived from what?
The Byzantine term Sklavinoi was loaned into Arabic as Saqaliba by who?
What English word does "sclave" come from?
What Latin word was a misunderstanding?
What word was loaned from Arabic?
Who disputes the origin of the word Saqaliba?

context: The English word <b4_0>Slav<b4_0/> could be derived from the Middle English word <a0_0>sclave<a0_0/>, which was borrowed from Medieval Latin <b5_0>sclavus or slavus<b5_0/>, itself a borrowing and Byzantine Greek σκλάβος sklábos "slave," which was in turn apparently derived from a <a2_0>misunderstanding of the Slavic autonym<a2_0/> (denoting a speaker of their own languages). The <b8_0>Byzantine<b8_0/> term <a1_0><b6_0>Sklavinoi<b6_0/><a1_0/> was loaned into Arabic as Saqaliba صقالبة (sing. Saqlabi صقلبي) by <a3_0><b7_0>medieval Arab historiographers<b7_0/><a3_0/>. However, the origin of this word is disputed.
